head.title: Size-Matching Ligand Insertion in MOF-74 for Enhanced CO2 Capture under Humid Conditions | The Journal of Physical Chemistry C

meta.content: Size-Matching Ligand Insertion in MOF-74 for Enhanced CO2 Capture under Humid Conditions

Among various class of materials, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are one of the most promising candidates for CO2 capture from flue gases. In particular, M-MOF-74, where M represents different metals, are equipped with open metal sites that can lead to very high CO2 uptake at postcombustion flue gas conditions. However, these structures are known to have poor CO2 capture performance under humid conditions as water molecules bind strongly to the unsaturated metal sites, outcompeting the CO2. In this computational study, a pore space partition strategy is employed through a symmetry-matching regulated ligand insertion within the Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74 structures, which mitigates the deterioration effect of water. In the case of Zn-MOF-74, higher selectivity as well as larger CO2 uptake in binary mixture conditions is obtained, thereby demonstrating that reduction in the pore size of MOFs can serve as viable strategy to capture CO2 under humid postcombustion conditions.

div.p:
Among various class of materials, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are one of the most promising candidates for CO
2
capture from flue gases. In particular, M-MOF-74, where M represents different metals, are equipped with open metal sites that can lead to very high CO
2
uptake at postcombustion flue gas conditions. However, these structures are known to have poor CO
2
capture performance under humid conditions as water molecules bind strongly to the unsaturated metal sites, outcompeting the CO
2
. In this computational study, a pore space partition strategy is employed through a symmetry-matching regulated ligand insertion within the Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74 structures, which mitigates the deterioration effect of water. In the case of Zn-MOF-74, higher selectivity as well as larger CO
2
uptake in binary mixture conditions is obtained, thereby demonstrating that reduction in the pore size of MOFs can serve as viable strategy to capture CO
2
under humid postcombustion conditions.

div.div:
The reduction of carbon dioxide from fossil-fuel-burning power plants has been one of the key environmental-related issues in recent years.
(1, 2)
The dire implications of global warming and climate change have prompted various research activities toward development of efficient methods for carbon dioxide (CO
2
) capture from industrial flue gas.
(3)
Traditionally, amine solutions have been primarily used to separate CO
2
from other flue gas components. Unfortunately, there are multiple drawbacks to amine, including high regeneration costs that have prompted researchers to look elsewhere in terms of developing new materials that can potentially replace the technology. As a result, solid adsorbent materials such as zeolites, activated carbons, and metalâorganic frameworks (MOFs) have been explored as alterative materials that can potentially reduce the CO
2
capture costs.
(4, 5)

Among various promising classes of materials, metalâorganic frameworks (MOFs) are viewed as one of the most promising candidates for CO
2
capture from flue gas.
(6, 7)
MOFs are crystalline microporous materials, formed by self-assembly between metal nodes and bridging organic linkers. With their large surface area, tunability, and presence of open metal sites in certain structures, many of the MOFs have shown excellent performance in terms of capturing CO
2
in dry flue gas conditions. Moreover, with amine-appended MOFs (as well as other porous materials), the chemisorption of CO
2
can lead to large CO
2
uptake even under humid conditions.
(8, 9)
Research works on stability of using amine groups in the MOFs under humid conditions have been studied by a few other groups.
(10-12)
And it has been stated that the key attribute to stability of MOFs in water is the absence of water clustering near the metal sites.
(12)
Unfortunately, the amine-appended MOFs still have similar drawbacks to the conventional amine technology due to the large regeneration costs, and as such, it is worthwhile to investigate sorbents that can operate well under humid conditions while still capturing CO
2
via physisorption processes.

Of the current MOF materials with open metal sites, M-MOF-74 with M = Mg, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn have exhibited exceptionally high CO
2
adsorption capacity under dry flue gas conditions.
(13-17)
Unfortunately, these structures are renowned to perform poorly under humid conditions as various experimental and computational works have shown deterioration in CO
2
capture performance under humid conditions for M-MOF-74 structures.
(18-20)
To improve upon these M-MOF-74 materials, one can potentially append various functional groups that can improve the CO
2
capture performances. In particular in the literature, several pore space partition strategies have been reported,
(21-23)
where regulated ligands were inserted at the center of the MOF frameworks. It has been noted that by inserting ligands into the MOFs, there is a trade-off between enhanced gasâhost interactions and reduced pore volume. In particular, Zhao et al.
(22)
demonstrated that insertion of 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligands in MIL-88 leads to enhanced CO
2
uptake in the low-pressure regime due to the creation of stronger CO
2
binding sites with the presence of the ligand. Given that postcombustion flue gas capture of CO
2
occurs at low partial pressures (e.g., 0.1â0.15 bar), ligand insertion can be used as a viable strategy to increase the working capacity of CO
2
. However, to the best of our knowledge, the effect that this type of modification has on CO
2
capture under humid, postcombustion conditions has not been explored.

To this end, in this work we have used computational simulations to systematically investigate two MOFs (Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74) to explore the effect of postsynthetic ligand inclusions on these materials. The project was initiated with the hypothesis that there might be dual benefits of enhanced CO
2
uptake at lower pressure regime (similar to work done by Zhao et al.
(22)
) as well as improved CO
2
capture performance under wet flue gas conditions as a result of this modification. The latter point was motivated by a recent computational CO
2
/H
2
O screening study conducted by Li et al.
(24)
where they observed that all of the best performing MOFs under humid conditions possessed relatively small pore sizes. This finding is consistent with the known observation that in porous materials with large pore sizes, the water molecules can aggregate with one another to form a large cluster, thereby completely saturating the pore with water. Additionally, Jeong et al.
(25)
investigated the CO
2
/H
2
O selective materials in zeolites and showed that the best structures have segregated sites with smaller pores as opposed to larger ones, further confirming the need to explore materials with small pore sizes.

This paper is organized as follows: In
Section 2
, the computational details of the quantum chemical calculations and classical Monte Carlo simulations are described. In
Section 3
, the computational results and discussions of this study are presented. Finally, we offer our concluding remarks in
Section 4
.

Optimization of M-MOF-74 structures and the small gas molecule (i.e., CO
2
and H
2
O) binding energy calculations were conducted using the first-principles calculations through the density functional theory (DFT) as implemented by the plane-wave pseudopotential approach in Quantum Espresso.
(26)
We used the second version of a van der Waals dispersion-corrected density functional (vdW-DF2)
(27)
as previous computational study on M-MOF-74 structures showed good agreement between the DFT energetics and experimental data (Lee et al.
(28)
). Ultrasoft pseudopotentials were used for GGA and vdW-DF2 calculations. The kinetic energy and charge density planewave cutoff were set to 30 and 240 Ry, respectively. A 2 Ã 2 Ã 2 k-point mesh was used for Brillouin zone sampling in the reciprocal space. The DFT adsorption energies of an individual gas molecule inside the MOF were calculated as follows
(1)

) are the total DFT energy of the MOF with the gas molecule adsorbed in the minimum energy configuration, the total energy of the MOF structures, and the energy of the gas molecule in the gas phase, respectively.

It is common practice to use DFT simulations to obtain force fields for MOF structures.
(29)
Recently for Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74 structures, Lin et al.
(30)
developed new force field parameters for CO
2
and H
2
O from periodic density functional theory (DFT) calculations. They demonstrated that the derived force field parameters were accurate in estimating the CO
2
and H
2
O adsorption properties in Mg-MOF-74 for Zn-MOF-74. As such, in this work, we used the force field parameters developed by Lin et al.
(30)
for the pure M-MOF-74 calculations as well as ligand-appended M-MOF-74 structures. CO
2
was modeled as a rigid molecule, and LJ parameters and partial charges were taken from the EPM2 force field.
(31)
For water, we used the conventional TIP4P-Ew model.
(32)

For the short-range repulsion term, two different types of potential forms were used: Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential type 1/

(30)
Nonelectrostatic pairwise potential is truncated and shifted to zero at the cutoff radius of 12.8 Ã .

To enable the description of the tpt ligand, UFF
(33)
parameters were used, and the partial point charges obtained from the DFT calculations (
Table S1
). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using a hybrid generalized gradient approximation with the B3LYP functional,
(34)
implemented in the GAUSSIAN 09 program (G09)
(35)
as the B3LYP has been demonstrated to show accurate geometry optimization results.
(36)
The 6-31G(d) basis set is used to describe all of the electrons in the system.

The ligand insertion and site partition of the MOF-74 structure can be a strategy to re-engineer the pore space to enhance the CO
2
capture performance. To demonstrate this, a size-matching regulated ligand (2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt)) was inserted as shown in
Figure 1
.

div.p:
Figure 1. Illustration of pore space partition MOF through a size-matching regulated ligand (2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt)). (a) Left side indicates noncrossed ligand insertion (100%) along the
z
axis and right side represents side view. (b) Left side indicates noncrossed ligand insertion (50%) along the
z
axis and right side represents side view. (c) Same as (a) but crossed ligand insertion (100%).

div.div:
Within the hexagonal channels of MOF-74, each of the three nitrogen (one per 4-pyridyl ligand) atoms are positioned adjacent to the channel center on the three sides (
Figure 1
a). Initially, the tpt ligands were inserted such that the distance between the two tpt ligands is 6.92 Ã along the channel direction in the
z
-axis (
Figure 1
a, right side), indicating that the tpt ligands are tightly packed while occupying all possible metal sites (100% occupancy). The orientations of the ligands were assumed to be the same along the
z
-axis, forming what we label as ânoncrossedâ configurations (
Figure 1
a). Upon relaxing the structure using DFT, the nearest distance between the tpt ligand atom (i.e., nitrogen) and the metal was found to be 2.30 Ã in Mg-MOF-74 and 2.25 Ã in Zn-MOF-74. The DFT binding energy of tpt ligand was computed to be â302.1 and â279.8 kJ/mol, for the Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74 structures, respectively, providing reliable support that the ligands would stay intact and not wash away, post synthesis. In subsequent sections, we explore the effect of having only 50% occupancy where the distance between the two tpt ligands is 13.83 Ã along the channel direction (
Figure 1
b), as well as having tpt linkers that are aligned in a âcrossedâ formation (
Figure 1
c) within the 100% occupancy configuration.

The computed CO
2
binding energy is â45.2 kJ/mol in Mg-MOF-74, which agrees well with the value of â45 kJ/mol obtained by Lee et al.
(28)
For the tpt-Mg-MOF-74, the CO
2
binding energy is â57.9 kJ/mol, which shows significant enhancement in the CO
2
binding strength in the presence of the ligand. Although there does not exist any experimental/computational data to verify this finding, qualitatively similar CO
2
adsorption enhancement effect at the Henry regime was experimentally observed in the ligand-appended MIL-88 structure.
(22)
Moreover, this type of CO
2
binding enhancement from two different molecular clusters is not too different from what we observed computationally with the CO
2
located at the interface between MOF-5 and graphene oxide in an earlier study.
(37)
The binding configurations from
Figure 2
show that the location of the CO
2
has shifted toward the nitrogen atom of the tpt ligand as the distance between the oxygen atom of the CO
2
and the Mg atom has increased from 2.32 to 2.42 Ã . In the case of Zn-MOF-74 and tpt-Zn-MOF-74, similar trends are observed with the respective CO
2
binding energies of â35.2 and â40.8 kJ/mol. The former value again agrees very well with the value (i.e., â34 kJ/mol) obtained by Lee et al.
(28)
Similar to the case for Mg-MOF-74, the location of the binding configuration of CO
2
has shifted toward the nitrogen atom of the tpt ligand as the distance between the oxygen atom of the CO
2
and the Zn atom increased from 2.67 to 2.76 Ã . The classical binding energy adsorption energies obtained from classical Monte Carlo simulations at very low temperature (i.e.,
T
= 15 K) reveal consistent values and similar trend as the DFT data (see
Supporting Information
Table S1).

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) Optimized configuration of CO
2
in Mg-MOF-74 (B.E: â45.2 kJ/mol). (b) CO
2
in tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (B.E: â57.9 kJ/mol). (c) CO
2
in Zn-MOF-74 (B.E: â35.2 kJ/mol). (d) CO
2
in tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (B.E: â40.8 kJ/mol). C, N, O, Mg, Zn, and H are shown in gray, blue, red, green, violet, and white colors, respectively. To better illustrate the binding configurations, the cluster was zoomed in and exterior atoms were omitted.

div.div:
Similar analysis was conducted for H
2
O as the optimized configurations are shown in
Figure 3
a and b. Compared to the case for CO
2
, in both M-MOF-74 and tpt-M-MOF-74, the H
2
O molecule binds stronger with the metal of the MOF-74 structure as the binding energies of H
2
O molecule are â85.5, â70.0, â69.5, and â51.7 kJ/mol, respectively, in tpt-Mg-MOF-74, tpt-Zn-MOF-74, Mg-MOF-74, and Zn-MOF-74. Unlike the case for CO
2
, the H
2
O molecule does not move toward the direction of the tpt ligand, indicating that the strongly adsorbed configurations in the M-MOF-74 cases dictate the binding configurations. The classical binding energy adsorption results at very low temperature (i.e.,
T
= 15 K) indicate similar trend and can be found in the
Supporting Information
(Table S2). The binding energy results of CO
2
and H
2
O molecules are summarized in
Table 1
.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) Optimized structures of H
2
O in Mg-MOF-74 (B.E: â69.5 kJ/mol). (b) Optimized structures of H
2
O in tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (B.E: â85.5 kJ/mol). (c) Optimized structures of H
2
O in Zn-MOF-74 (B.E: â51.7 kJ/mol). (d) Optimized structures of H
2
O in tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (B.E: â70.0 kJ/mol). C, N, O, Mg, Zn, and H are shown in gray, blue, red, green, violet, and white colors, respectively.

div.div: Table 1. Binding Energies (in kJ/mol) for Gas Molecules in M-MOF-74 Structures

div.h3:
Pure Component CO
2
and H
2
O Adsorption Isotherms
div.div:
Both the CO
2
and the H
2
O adsorption isotherms were computed with the force field parameters described in the
Methodology
section. The isotherms for three tpt configurations (crossed insertion at 100%, noncrossed insertion at 100%, and noncrossed insertion at 50%) along with the pure M-MOF-74 (M = Mg, Zn) cases (both experimental
(38)
and computational for the case of CO
2
) are shown in
Figure 4
. The N
2
adsorption isotherm was also calculated at both 298 and 313 K (
Figure S3
).

div.p:
Figure 4. At 298 K, (a) CO
2
adsorption isotherm in Mg-MOF-74, tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (50%), tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%), tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%, crossed), and Mg-MOF-74 (exp.) represented by black, green, blue, red, and orange squares, respectively. (b) Same as (a) except for H
2
O with circle representations. (c) Same as (a) but in Zn-MOF-74 and tpt-Zn-MOF-74. (d) Same as (b) but in Zn-MOF-74 and tpt-Zn-MOF-74. In (a)â(d), the inset figures show the zoomed part at the low-pressure region of the isotherms.

div.div:
As expected from the DFT binding energy data, the CO
2
isotherms show exceptionally high uptake at the low-pressure Henry region with the insertion of the tpt ligand for both the Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74. It is interesting to note that the trade-off between reduced the number of available open metal sites (due to ligand binding) and strengthening of CO
2
binding sites due to the presence of tpt ligands tilts toward the favor of the latter as CO
2
uptake becomes larger at low pressures. However, at
P
= 0.022, 0.014, and 0.032 bar, the CO
2
uptake of tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%, crossed), tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%), and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (50%) intersects with the corresponding pure Mg-MOF-74 adsorption isotherm curve, beyond which Mg-MOF-74 has larger CO
2
uptake (due to more available pore volume). Similar results hold for Zn-MOF-74 as at pressures of 0.6, 0.63, and 0.68 bar: the CO
2
uptake of tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (100%, crossed), tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (100%, noncrossed), and tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (50%) intersects that of pure Zn-MOF-74 curve. It is interesting to note that these crossing point pressures for Zn-MOF-74 are significantly higher than those of Mg-MOF-74, indicating that for a wider range of pressure values, Zn-MOF-74 benefits more with the ligand inclusion as opposed to Mg-MOF-74 in terms of CO
2
uptake enhancement. This might be a general conclusion where MOFs with weaker CO
2
binding sites benefit more from ligand insertions as there is more room for enhancement in gas adsorption.

Our computational results also indicate that crossed insertion of the tpt ligand (red curve in inset of
Figure 4
) leads to larger CO
2
uptake compared to the noncrossed ligand insertion (blue curve in inset of
Figure 4
) at the same proportion of 100% ligands. To understand why this is the case, the classical CO
2
binding energy configurations at
T
= 15 K were compared between the crossed and noncrossed tpt ligand structures as shown in
Figure 5
. In both Mg-MOF-74 (
Figure 5
a, b) and Zn-MOF-74 (
Figure 5
c, d), it can be seen that the oxygen atoms of the CO
2
molecules are closer to the adjacent ligand atoms in the crossed case, creating a more attractive binding site for the CO
2
compared to the noncrossed cases.

div.p:
Figure 5. Classical binding energy configurations with (a) CO
2
in tpt-Mg-MOF-74(100%), (b) CO
2
in tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%, crossed), (c) CO
2
in tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (100%), and (d) CO
2
in tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (100%, crossed). C, N, O, Mg, Zn, and H are shown in gray, blue, red, green, violet, and white colors, respectively..

div.div:
In the case of H
2
O, the ligand inclusion leads to enhancement for a much smaller range of pressures: most notably, at pressures of 9.3 Ã 10
â7
, 5.7 Ã 10
â7
, and 1.6 Ã 10
â6
bar, the H
2
O adsorption isotherm curves of tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%, crossed), tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%), and tpt-Mg- MOF-74 (50%) cross that of the isotherm curves of H
2
O in pure Mg-MOF-74 structure. For both CO
2
and H
2
O, at high-pressure value of
P
= 100 bar the uptake amount in the tpt-MOF-74 structures is much less than that without the ligand, which can be intuitively explained by the effective reduction in the overall pore volume with the ligand inclusions. Finally, the results at a different temperature of
T
= 313 K are shown in the
Supporting Information
, and qualitatively, the simulated data show similar trends from
T
= 298 K (
Figure S1
).

div.h3:
CO
2
/H
2
O Mixture IAST in M-MOF-74 (M = Mg and Zn)
div.div:
The three most prominent gases in typical postcombustion flue gas mixtures are CO
2
, H
2
O, and N
2
. In M-MOF-74 (M = Mg, Zn), N
2
has a much weaker binding energy than CO
2
and H
2
O. In addition, Li et al.
(24)
shows the CO
2
/H
2
O selectivity for the materials that is insensitive to the presence of N
2
. The work of Lin et al.
(30)
also neglected N
2
composition in mixture simulation because N
2
has a weaker binding energy than CO
2
and H
2
O (that said, the section on CO
2
/N
2
(in absence of water) as well as mixture analysis and breakthrough curves can be found in Section S4 in the
Supporting Information
). For that reason, only the binary mixtures of CO
2
and H
2
O were considered in the analysis with the N
2
deemed to have negligible effect on the overall CO
2
capture performance. The total pressure of the flue gas was set to be 0.15 bar, with varying H
2
O mole fraction values ranging from 0.001% to 10%. Our newly developed IAST code (IAST++
https://sites.google.com/site/iastcpp
) was used to predict the uptake at each specific composition. The IAST data was cross-checked with the mixture GCMC simulation data, and the results agree relatively well (see
Supporting Information
, Figure S2).

For the mixture analysis, we focused on observing the effect of the various ligand configurations on the H
2
O mole fraction in which the CO
2
and the H
2
O isotherm curves cross one another. At higher H
2
O content beyond this crossing point, the H
2
O uptake starts to dominate, and the material is rendered useless for CO
2
capture, and as such this crossing point pressure needs to be as large as possible to operate in a wider range of moist flue gas conditions. For the CO
2
/H
2
O mixtures inside tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%, crossed) and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%), the IAST results show that the uptake of CO
2
becomes equal to that of H
2
O at the mole fractions of 0.016% and 0.035%, respectively, compared to the case of pure Mg-MOF-74, which is at 0.007% (
Figure 6
a), implying that addition of ligands leads to wider range of acceptable H
2
O content for CO
2
capture. It turns out that the smaller pores resulting from 100% occupied ligand provide strong binding of CO
2
and limit water uptake at high humidity by preventing the formation of water clusters inside the pores. Similarly, for the mixture inside tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (100%, crossed) and tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (100%), uptake of CO
2
becomes equal to H
2
O at water mole fractions of 0.265% and 0.432%, respectively, showing improvement over 0.183% for the pure Zn-MOF-74 case (
Figure 6
b). In the case of tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (100% crossed and 100%), there is added benefit of enhancement of the CO
2
uptake with the addition of the ligands (solid red and blue lines are above the black line in
Figure 6
b for a wide range of H
2
O mole fraction content), making ligand insertion an attractive design strategy to enhance CO
2
capture in moist conditions. Implicit in this result is that to optimize the ligand insertion strategy, it might be beneficial to start with a MOF that possesses relatively weak CO
2
binding sites to simultaneously allow higher CO
2
adsorption and more resistance to H
2
O.

div.p:
Figure 6. Binary mixture of CO
2
(solid lines) and H
2
O (dashed lines) inside (a) Mg-MOF-74 (black), tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (50%) (green), tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%) (blue), and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (100%, crossed) (red) as a function of H
2
O mole fraction at total pressure of 0.15 bar and
T
= 298 K. (b) Same as (a) but with Zn-MOF-74.

div.div:
On the other hand, by looking at 50% ligand content for tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (50%) and tpt-Zn-MOF-74 (50%), there is a reduction in the H
2
O mole fraction content where CO
2
is equal to H
2
O (0.005% and 0.139%, respectively) compared to the pure M-MOF-74 cases (0.007% and 0.183%, respectively). To explore the reasoning behind this phenomena, CO
2
and H
2
O pure component isotherms were obtained for varying percentage of ligands (i.e., 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100%), and the mixture isotherm crossing H
2
O mole fraction points were obtained (similar to
Figure 6
).

The results summarized in
Figure 7
for both Mg-MOF-74 (
Figure 7
a) and Zn-MOF-74 (
Figure 7
b indicate that the crossing point has a minimum (implying the worst performance) at 50% ligand inserted and maximum (implying the best performance) at 100% inserted cases. In general, there is a trade-off between pore volume (where larger pore volume leads to more water clustering) versus the inclusion of ligands strengthening the CO
2
adsorption. In Mg-MOF-74, the CO
2
uptake decreases with increasing proportion of ligands whereas the trend is opposite in the case for Zn-MOF-74 (
Figure 7
, green curves). This affirms our earlier hypothesis indicating that ligand inclusion is more beneficial for metals with weaker CO
2
binding sites in these humid conditions.

div.p:
Figure 7. Crossing point H
2
O mole fraction (%) versus ligand proportion (%) for (a) tpt-Mg-MOF-74 and (b) tpt-Zn-MOF-74. Left
y
-axis indicates the H
2
O mole fraction at the crossing point between CO
2
and H
2
O (closed black squares with line). Right
y
-axis indicates the IAST CO
2
uptake as a function of ligand proportion at a total pressure of 0.15 bar (open green squares with line). The black and the green dotted arrows indicate the correspondence to the left (black) and the right (green)
y
-axes, respectively.

div.div:
In this work, we used size-matching ligand insertion to partition the pore spaces in M-MOF-74 (M = Mg, Zn). Using both DFT and classical Monte Carlo simulations, we revealed that inclusion of ligands in tpt-M-MOF-74 (M = Mg, Zn) leads to higher uptake for CO
2
. In addition, the mixture IAST analysis showed that the CO
2
uptake performance under humid conditions in both tpt-Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Zn-MOF-74 can improve significantly. As such, our work can serve as a blueprint for experimentalists interested in designing the optimal CO
2
capture materials for humid conditions. Beyond our results for the MOF-74 type of materials, we believe that our work has a broader scope and leads to the following general conclusion: MOFs that possess moderately strong binding sites and large pore volumes are good starting structures for postsynthetic modifications as insertions of ligands can optimize the CO
2
binding sites under humid conditions and prevent water clustering.

Observational determination of surface radiative forcing by CO2 from 2000 to 2010
Feldman, D. R.; Collins, W. D.; Gero, P. J.; Torn, M. S.; Mlawer, E. J.; Shippert, T. R.

The climate impact of CO2 and other greenhouse gases is usually quantified in terms of radiative forcing, calcd. as the difference between estd. Earth radiation field from pre-industrial vs. present-day concns. of these gases. Radiative transfer models calc. the increase in CO2 since 1750 corresponds to a global annual-mean radiative forcing at the tropopause of 1.82 Â± 0.19 W/m2 (G. Myhre, 2013). However, despite widespread scientific discussion and modeling of the climate impacts of well-mixed greenhouse gases, there is little direct observational evidence of the radiative impact of increasing atm. CO2. This work presents observationally based evidence of clear-sky CO2 surface radiative forcing directly attributable to the increase, from 2000 to 2010, of 22 ppm atm. CO2. The time series of this forcing at 2 sites (southern Great Plains and Alaska North Slope) were derived from atm. emitted radiance interferometer spectra together with ancillary measurements, thoroughly corroborated radiative transfer calcns. The time series both showed statistically significant trends of 0.2 W/m2-decade (with resp. uncertainties of Â±0.06 W/m2-decade and Â±0.07 W/m2- decade) and have seasonal ranges of 0.1-0.2 W/m2. This is â¼10% of the trend in down-welling long-wave radiation. These results confirm theor. predictions of the atm. greenhouse effect due to anthropogenic emissions and provide empirical evidence of how rising CO2 concns., mediated by temporal variations due to photosynthesis and respiration, are affecting the surface energy balance.

D'Alessandro, Deanna M.; Smit, Berend; Long, Jeffrey R.

A review. The escalating level of atm. carbon dioxide is one of the most pressing environmental concerns of our age. Carbon capture and storage (CCS) from large point sources such as power plants is one option for reducing anthropogenic CO2 emissions; however, currently the capture alone will increase the energy requirements of a plant by 25-40%. This review highlights the challenges for capture technologies which have the greatest likelihood of reducing CO2 emissions to the atm., namely postcombustion (predominantly CO2/N2 sepn.), precombustion (CO2/H2) capture, and natural gas sweetening (CO2/CH4). The key factor which underlies significant advancements lies in improved materials that perform the sepns. In this regard, the most recent developments and emerging concepts in CO2 sepns. by solvent absorption, chem. and phys. adsorption, and membranes, amongst others, will be discussed, with particular attention on progress in the burgeoning field of metal-org. frameworks.

Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.
Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)

An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework. The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons. Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column. The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail. The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated. The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites. The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes. A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.

Cooperative insertion of CO2 in diamine-appended metal-organic frameworks
McDonald, Thomas M.; Mason, Jarad A.; Kong, Xueqian; Bloch, Eric D.; Gygi, David; Dani, Alessandro; Crocella, Valentina; Giordanino, Filippo; Odoh, Samuel O.; Drisdell, Walter S.; Vlaisavljevich, Bess; Dzubak, Allison L.; Poloni, Roberta; Schnell, Sondre K.; Planas, Nora; Lee, Kyuho; Pascal, Tod; Wan, Liwen F.; Prendergast, David; Neaton, Jeffrey B.; Smit, Berend; Kortright, Jeffrey B.; Gagliardi, Laura; Bordiga, Silvia; Reimer, Jeffrey A.; Long, Jeffrey R.

519
(

303-308
CODEN:
NATUAS
; ISSN:
0028-0836
.
(
Nature Publishing Group
)
The process of carbon capture and sequestration has been proposed as a method of mitigating the build-up of greenhouse gases in the atm. If implemented, the cost of electricity generated by a fossil fuel-burning power plant would rise substantially, owing to the expense of removing CO2 from the effluent stream. There is therefore an urgent need for more efficient gas sepn. technologies, such as those potentially offered by advanced solid adsorbents. Here we show that diamine-appended metal-org. frameworks can behave as 'phase-change' adsorbents, with unusual step-shaped CO2 adsorption isotherms that shift markedly with temp. Results from spectroscopic, diffraction and computational studies show that the origin of the sharp adsorption step is an unprecedented cooperative process in which, above a metal-dependent threshold pressure, CO2 mols. insert into metal-amine bonds, inducing a reorganization of the amines into well-ordered chains of ammonium carbamate. As a consequence, large CO2 sepn. capacities can be achieved with small temp. swings, and regeneration energies appreciably lower than achievable with state-of-the-art aq. amine solns. become feasible. The results provide a mechanistic framework for designing highly efficient adsorbents for removing CO2 from various gas mixts., and yield insights into the conservation of Mg2+ within the ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase family of enzymes.

CO2 induced phase transitions in diamine-appended metal-organic frameworks
Vlaisavljevich, Bess; Odoh, Samuel O.; Schnell, Sondre K.; Dzubak, Allison L.; Lee, Kyuho; Planas, Nora; Neaton, Jeffrey B.; Gagliardi, Laura; Smit, Berend

Using a combination of d. functional theory and lattice models, we study the effect of CO2 adsorption in an amine functionalized metal-org. framework. These materials exhibit a step in the adsorption isotherm indicative of a phase change. The pressure at which this step occurs is not only temp. dependent but is also metal center dependent. Likewise, the heats of adsorption vary depending on the metal center. Herein we demonstrate via quantum chem. calcns. that the amines should not be considered firmly anchored to the framework and we explore the mechanism for CO2 adsorption. An ammonium carbamate species is formed via the insertion of CO2 into the M-Namine bonds. Furthermore, we translate the quantum chem. results into isotherms using a coarse grained Monte Carlo simulation technique and show that this adsorption mechanism can explain the characteristic step obsd. in the exptl. isotherm while a previously proposed mechanism cannot. Furthermore, metal analogs have been explored and the CO2 binding energies show a strong metal dependence corresponding to the M-Namine bond strength. We show that this difference can be exploited to tune the pressure at which the step in the isotherm occurs. Addnl., the mmen-Ni2(dobpdc) framework shows Langmuir like behavior, and our simulations show how this can be explained by competitive adsorption between the new model and a previously proposed model.

Tremendous efforts have been devoted to increasing the CO2 capture performance of porous materials, esp. for low CO2 concn. environments. Here, we report that hydrazine can be used as a diamine short enough to functionalize the small-pore metal-org. framework [Mg2(dobdc)] (H4dobdc = 2,5-dihydroxyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid). By virtue of the ultrahigh concn. of free amine groups (6.01 mmol g-1 or 7.08 mmol cm-3) capable of reversible carbamic acid formation, the new material [Mg2(dobdc)(N2H4)1.8] achieves a series of new records for CO2 capture, such as single-component isotherm uptakes of 3.89 mmol g-1 or 4.58 mmol cm-3 at the atm. CO2 concn. of 0.4 mbar at 298 K and 1.04 mmol g-1 or 1.22 mmol cm-3 at 328 K, as well as more than a 4.2 mmol g-1 or 4.9 mmol cm-3 adsorption/desorption working capacity under dynamic mixed-gas conditions with CO2 concns. similar to those in flue gases and ambient air.

Incorporation of Alkylamine into Metal-Organic Frameworks through a Bronsted Acid-Base Reaction for CO2 Capture
Li, Hao; Wang, Kecheng; Feng, Dawei; Chen, Ying-Pin; Verdegaal, Wolfgang; Zhou, Hong-Cai

The escalating atm. CO2 concn. is one of the most urgent environmental concerns of our age. To effectively capture CO2, various materials have been studied. Among them, alkylamine-modified metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are considered to be promising candidates. In most cases, alkylamine mols. are integrated into MOFs through the coordination bonds formed between open metal sites (OMSs) and amine groups. Thus, the alkylamine d., as well as the corresponding CO2 uptake in MOFs, are severely restricted by the d. of OMSs. To overcome this limit, other approaches to incorporating alkylamine into MOFs are highly desired. We have developed a new method based on Bronsted acid-base reaction to tether alkylamines into Cr-MIL-101-SO3H for CO2 capture. A systematic optimization of the amine tethering process was also conducted to maximize the CO2 uptake of the modified MOF. Under the optimal amine tethering condition, the obtained tris(2-aminoethyl)amine-functionalized Cr-MIL-101-SO3H (Cr-MIL-101-SO3H-TAEA) has a cyclic CO2 uptake of 2.28 mmol g-1 at 150 mbar and 40 Â°C, and 1.12 mmol g-1 at 0.4 mbar and 20 Â°C. The low-cost starting materials and simple synthetic procedure for the prepn. of Cr-MIL-101-SO3H-TAEA suggest that it has the potential for large-scale prodn. and practical applications.

Ab initio carbon capture in open-site metal-organic frameworks
Dzubak, Allison L.; Lin, Li-Chiang; Kim, Jihan; Swisher, Joseph A.; Poloni, Roberta; Maximoff, Sergey N.; Smit, Berend; Gagliardi, Laura

During the formation of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), metal centers can coordinate with the intended org. linkers, but also with solvent mols. In this case, subsequent activation by removal of the solvent mols. creates unsatd. open metal sites known to have a strong affinity to CO2 mols., but their interactions are still poorly understood. Common force fields typically underestimate by as much as 2 orders of magnitude the adsorption of CO2 in open-site Mg-MOF-74, which has emerged as a promising MOF for CO2 capture. We present a systematic procedure to generate force fields using high-level quantum chem. calcns. Monte Carlo simulations based on an ab initio force field generated for CO2 in Mg-MOF-74 shed some light on the interpretation of thermodn. data from flue gas in this material. The force field describes accurately the chem. of the open metal sites, and is transferable to other structures. This approach may serve in mol. simulations in general and in the study of fluid-solid interactions.

Highly efficient separation of carbon dioxide by a metal-organic framework replete with open metal sites
Britt, David; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Wang, Bo; Glover, T. Grant; Yaghi, Omar M.

Selective capture of CO2, which is essential for natural gas purifn. and CO2 sequestration, has been reported in zeolites, porous membranes, and amine solns. However, all such systems require substantial energy input for release of captured CO2, leading to low energy efficiency and high cost. A new class of materials named metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has also been demonstrated to take up voluminous amts. of CO2. However, these studies have been largely limited to equil. uptake measurements, which are a poor predictor of sepn. ability, rather than the more industrially relevant kinetic (dynamic) capacity. Here, we report that a known MOF, Mg-MOF-74, with open magnesium sites, rivals competitive materials in CO2 capture, with 8.9 wt. % dynamic capacity, and undergoes facile CO2 release at significantly lower temp., 80 Â°C. Mg-MOF-74 offers an excellent balance between dynamic capacity and regeneration. These results demonstrate the potential of MOFs with open metal sites as efficient CO2 capture media.

Metal-org. framework (MOF) compds. M2(dhtp) (open metal M = Mg, Mn, Co, Ni, Zn; dhtp = 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalate) possess exceptionally large densities of open metal sites. By adsorbing one CH4 mol. per open metal, these sites alone can generate very large methane storage capacities, 160-174 cm3(STP)/cm3, approaching the DOE target of 180 cm3(STP)/cm3 for material-based methane storage at room temp. The adsorption isotherm measurements at 298 K and 35 bar for the five M2(dhtp) compds. yield excess methane adsorption capacities ranging from 149 to 190 cm3(STP)/cm3 (derived using their crystal densities), indeed roughly equal to the predicted, maximal adsorption capacities of the open metals (within Â±10%) in these MOFs. Among the five isostructural MOFs studied, Ni2(dhtp) exhibits the highest methane storage capacity, â¼200 cm3(STP)/cm3 in terms of abs. adsorption, potentially surpassing the DOE target by â¼10%. The neutron diffraction expts. clearly reveal that the primary CH4 adsorption occurs directly on the open metal sites. Initial 1st-principles calcns. show that the binding energies of CH4 on the open metal sites are significantly higher than those on typical adsorption sites in classical MOFs, consistent with the measured large heats of methane adsorption for these materials. The authors attribute the enhancement of the binding strength to the unscreened electrostatic interaction between CH4 and the coordinatively unsatd. metal ions.

H2O effects on postcombustion CO2 capture in Mg-MOF-74 are evaluated by using a combination of Grand Canonical Monte Carlo and d. functional theory (DFT) simulations. Results show that in this MOF the CO2 adsorption capacity is decreased by the presence of H2O mols. linked to coordinatively unsatd. metal sites (CUMs). DFT calcns. indicate that such binding energy is much lower than that without coordinated H2O. More importantly, the difference of the binding energy between CO2 and CUM in a MOF and between CO2 and CUM-coordinated H2O are good descriptors to evaluate H2O effects on CO2 capture in MOFs with CUMs. At the same time, these studies further demonstrate that the CUMs in MOFs play an important role in their performance for CO2 capture from a practical stream contg. Metal org. framework (MOF) materials in general, and MOF-74 in particular, have promising properties for many technol. important processes. However, their instability under humid conditions severely restricts practical use. We show that this instability and the accompanying redn. of the CO2 uptake capacity of MOF-74 under humid conditions originate in the water dissocn. reaction H2O â OH + H at the metal centers. After this dissocn., the OH groups coordinate to the metal centers, explaining the redn. in the MOF's CO2 uptake capacity. This redn. thus strongly depends on the catalytic activity of MOF-74 towards the water dissocn. reaction. We further show that-while the water mols. themselves only have a negligible effect on the crystal structure of MOF-74-the OH and H products of the dissocn. reaction significantly weaken the MOF framework and lead to the obsd. crystal structure breakdown. With this knowledge, we propose a way to suppress this particular reaction by modifying the MOF-74 structure to increase the water dissocn. energy barrier and thus control the stability of the system under humid conditions.

Pore Space Partition in Metal-Organic Frameworks
Zhai, Quan-Guo; Bu, Xianhui; Zhao, Xiang; Li, Dong-Sheng; Feng, Pingyun

A review. The efforts to implement pore space partition (PSP) in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and impact of PSP on gas uptake performance are reviewed. In the synthetic design of PSP, it is helpful to distinguish between factors that contribute to the framework formation and factors that serve the purpose of PSP. Because of the need for complementary structural roles, the synthesis of MOFs with PSP often involves multicomponent systems including mixed ligands, mixed inorg. nodes, or both. It is possible to accomplish both framework formation and PSP with a single type of polyfunctional ligands that use some functional groups (called framework-forming group) for framework formation and the remaining functional groups (called pore-partition group) for PSP. Alternatively, framework formation and PSP can be shouldered by different chem. species. For example, in a mixed-ligand system, one ligand (called framework-forming agent) can play the role of the framework formation while the other type of ligand (called pore-partition agent) can assume the role of PSP. PSP is sensitive to the types of inorg. secondary building units (SBUs). The coexistence of SBUs complementary in charge, connectivity, and so on can promote PSP. The use of heterometallic systems can promote the diversity of SBUs coexistent under a given condition. Heterometallic system with metal ions of different oxidn. states also provides the charge tunability of SBUs and the overall framework, providing an addnl. level of control in self-assembly and ultimately in the materials' properties. Of particular interest is the PSP in MIL-88 type (acs-type topol.) structure, which has led to a huge family of CPMs (called pacs CPMs, pacs = partitioned acs) exhibiting low isosteric heat of adsorption and yet superior CO2 uptake capacity.

Hubbard U corrections were applied to the localized d electrons of transition metal atoms, and the impact of such corrections was assessed quant. For systems for which measured binding enthalpies have been reported, these calcns. lead to excellent overall agreement with exptl. detd. structures and isosteric heats of adsorption. For systems that have yet to be realized or characterized, this study provides quant. predictions, establishes a better understanding of the role of different transition-metal cations in small-mol. binding at open-metal sites, and identifies routes for predicting potential candidates for energy-related gas-sepn. applications. For the 622 compds., the mean abs. errors (MAE) in the heats of formation are 3.1, 2.6, 2.7, and 2.4 kcal/mol for B3LYP/6-31G(d), B3LYP/6-31G(d,p), B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p), and B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) with the dispersion correction. The corresponding MAEs for the isomerizations are 2.7, 2.4, 2.2, and 1.9 kcal/mol. Improvement is obtained for isomerizations of amines and alcs. when both polarization and diffuse functions are used, but the overstabilization of linear alkanes compared to branched isomers can be relieved only with the dispersion correction. Besides the insights on DFT methods, the study also aimed to quantify the gains in accuracy that can be achieved by replacing energetics from NDO-based semiempirical methods with DFT results. A combined experimental and quantum chemical study of CO2 adsorption in the metal-organic framework CPO-27 with different metals
Yu, Decai; Yazaydin, A. Ozgur; Lane, Joseph R.; Dietzel, Pascal D. C.; Snurr, Randall Q.
Chemical Science

(
9
),
3544-3556
CODEN:

; ISSN:
2041-6520
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A first principles study of CO2 adsorption is presented for a group of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) known as CPO-27-M, where M = Mg, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn. These materials consist of one-dimensional channels with a high concn. of open metal sites and have been identified as among the most promising MOFs for CO2 capture. In addn., extensive, high-pressure, exptl. adsorption results are reported for CO2, CH4, and N2 at temps. ranging from 278 K to 473 K. Isosteric heats of adsorption were calcd. from the variable-temp. isotherms. The binding energies of CO2 calcd. using an MP2-based QM/MM method are in good agreement with those obtained from expts. The relative CO2 binding strengths for the different transition metals can be explained by the relative strength of electrostatic interactions caused by the effective charge of the metal atom in the direction of the open metal site induced by incomplete screening of 3d electrons. The Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu versions of CPO-27 are predicted to be anti-ferromagnetic in their ground states. Selectivities for CO2 over CH4 or N2 were calcd. from the exptl. isotherms using ideal adsorbed soln. theory.

span.span: Observational Determination of Surface Radiative Forcing by CO2 from 2000 to 2010

div.div:
[
Crossref
], [

1
Observational determination of surface radiative forcing by CO2 from 2000 to 2010
Feldman, D. R.; Collins, W. D.; Gero, P. J.; Torn, M. S.; Mlawer, E. J.; Shippert, T. R.
Nature (London, United Kingdom)
(
2015
),
519
(
7543
),
339-343
CODEN:
NATUAS
; ISSN:
0028-0836
.
(
Nature Publishing Group
)
The climate impact of CO2 and other greenhouse gases is usually quantified in terms of radiative forcing, calcd. as the difference between estd. Earth radiation field from pre-industrial vs. present-day concns. of these gases. Radiative transfer models calc. the increase in CO2 since 1750 corresponds to a global annual-mean radiative forcing at the tropopause of 1.82 Â± 0.19 W/m2 (G. Myhre, 2013). However, despite widespread scientific discussion and modeling of the climate impacts of well-mixed greenhouse gases, there is little direct observational evidence of the radiative impact of increasing atm. CO2. This work presents observationally based evidence of clear-sky CO2 surface radiative forcing directly attributable to the increase, from 2000 to 2010, of 22 ppm atm. CO2. The time series of this forcing at 2 sites (southern Great Plains and Alaska North Slope) were derived from atm. emitted radiance interferometer spectra together with ancillary measurements, thoroughly corroborated radiative transfer calcns. The time series both showed statistically significant trends of 0.2 W/m2-decade (with resp. uncertainties of Â±0.06 W/m2-decade and Â±0.07 W/m2- decade) and have seasonal ranges of 0.1-0.2 W/m2. This is â¼10% of the trend in down-welling long-wave radiation. These results confirm theor. predictions of the atm. greenhouse effect due to anthropogenic emissions and provide empirical evidence of how rising CO2 concns., mediated by temporal variations due to photosynthesis and respiration, are affecting the surface energy balance.

Carbon Dioxide Capture: prospects for New Materials
D'Alessandro, Deanna M.; Smit, Berend; Long, Jeffrey R.

(

(

A review. The escalating level of atm. carbon dioxide is one of the most pressing environmental concerns of our age. Carbon capture and storage (CCS) from large point sources such as power plants is one option for reducing anthropogenic CO2 emissions; however, currently the capture alone will increase the energy requirements of a plant by 25-40%. This review highlights the challenges for capture technologies which have the greatest likelihood of reducing CO2 emissions to the atm., namely postcombustion (predominantly CO2/N2 sepn.), precombustion (CO2/H2) capture, and natural gas sweetening (CO2/CH4). The key factor which underlies significant advancements lies in improved materials that perform the sepns. In this regard, the most recent developments and emerging concepts in CO2 sepns. by solvent absorption, chem. and phys. adsorption, and membranes, amongst others, will be discussed, with particular attention on progress in the burgeoning field of metal-org. frameworks.

[

5
Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.
Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)
(
2012
),
112
(
2
),
724-781
CODEN:
CHREAY
; ISSN:
0009-2665
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework. The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons. Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column. The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail. The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated. The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites. The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes. A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.

div.div:

Cooperative insertion of CO2 in diamine-appended metal-organic frameworks
McDonald, Thomas M.; Mason, Jarad A.; Kong, Xueqian; Bloch, Eric D.; Gygi, David; Dani, Alessandro; Crocella, Valentina; Giordanino, Filippo; Odoh, Samuel O.; Drisdell, Walter S.; Vlaisavljevich, Bess; Dzubak, Allison L.; Poloni, Roberta; Schnell, Sondre K.; Planas, Nora; Lee, Kyuho; Pascal, Tod; Wan, Liwen F.; Prendergast, David; Neaton, Jeffrey B.; Smit, Berend; Kortright, Jeffrey B.; Gagliardi, Laura; Bordiga, Silvia; Reimer, Jeffrey A.; Long, Jeffrey R.
Nature (London, United Kingdom)
(
2015
),
519
(
7543
),
303-308
CODEN:
NATUAS
; ISSN:
0028-0836
.
(
Nature Publishing Group
)
The process of carbon capture and sequestration has been proposed as a method of mitigating the build-up of greenhouse gases in the atm. If implemented, the cost of electricity generated by a fossil fuel-burning power plant would rise substantially, owing to the expense of removing CO2 from the effluent stream. There is therefore an urgent need for more efficient gas sepn. technologies, such as those potentially offered by advanced solid adsorbents. Here we show that diamine-appended metal-org. frameworks can behave as 'phase-change' adsorbents, with unusual step-shaped CO2 adsorption isotherms that shift markedly with temp. Results from spectroscopic, diffraction and computational studies show that the origin of the sharp adsorption step is an unprecedented cooperative process in which, above a metal-dependent threshold pressure, CO2 mols. insert into metal-amine bonds, inducing a reorganization of the amines into well-ordered chains of ammonium carbamate. As a consequence, large CO2 sepn. capacities can be achieved with small temp. swings, and regeneration energies appreciably lower than achievable with state-of-the-art aq. amine solns. become feasible. The results provide a mechanistic framework for designing highly efficient adsorbents for removing CO2 from various gas mixts., and yield insights into the conservation of Mg2+ within the ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase family of enzymes.

CO2 induced phase transitions in diamine-appended metal-organic frameworks
Vlaisavljevich, Bess; Odoh, Samuel O.; Schnell, Sondre K.; Dzubak, Allison L.; Lee, Kyuho; Planas, Nora; Neaton, Jeffrey B.; Gagliardi, Laura; Smit, Berend

5177-5185

; ISSN:
2041-6520

(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Using a combination of d. functional theory and lattice models, we study the effect of CO2 adsorption in an amine functionalized metal-org. framework. These materials exhibit a step in the adsorption isotherm indicative of a phase change. The pressure at which this step occurs is not only temp. dependent but is also metal center dependent. Likewise, the heats of adsorption vary depending on the metal center. Herein we demonstrate via quantum chem. calcns. that the amines should not be considered firmly anchored to the framework and we explore the mechanism for CO2 adsorption. An ammonium carbamate species is formed via the insertion of CO2 into the M-Namine bonds. Furthermore, we translate the quantum chem. results into isotherms using a coarse grained Monte Carlo simulation technique and show that this adsorption mechanism can explain the characteristic step obsd. in the exptl. isotherm while a previously proposed mechanism cannot. Furthermore, metal analogs have been explored and the CO2 binding energies show a strong metal dependence corresponding to the M-Namine bond strength. We show that this difference can be exploited to tune the pressure at which the step in the isotherm occurs. Addnl., the mmen-Ni2(dobpdc) framework shows Langmuir like behavior, and our simulations show how this can be explained by competitive adsorption between the new model and a previously proposed model.

Liao, Pei-Qin; Chen, Xun-Wei; Liu, Si-Yang; Li, Xu-Yu; Xu, Yan-Tong; Tang, Minni; Rui, Zebao; Ji, Hongbing; Zhang, Jie-Peng; Chen, Xiao-Ming

Tremendous efforts have been devoted to increasing the CO2 capture performance of porous materials, esp. for low CO2 concn. environments. Here, we report that hydrazine can be used as a diamine short enough to functionalize the small-pore metal-org. framework [Mg2(dobdc)] (H4dobdc = 2,5-dihydroxyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid). By virtue of the ultrahigh concn. of free amine groups (6.01 mmol g-1 or 7.08 mmol cm-3) capable of reversible carbamic acid formation, the new material [Mg2(dobdc)(N2H4)1.8] achieves a series of new records for CO2 capture, such as single-component isotherm uptakes of 3.89 mmol g-1 or 4.58 mmol cm-3 at the atm. CO2 concn. of 0.4 mbar at 298 K and 1.04 mmol g-1 or 1.22 mmol cm-3 at 328 K, as well as more than a 4.2 mmol g-1 or 4.9 mmol cm-3 adsorption/desorption working capacity under dynamic mixed-gas conditions with CO2 concns. similar to those in flue gases and ambient air.

Incorporation of Alkylamine into Metal-Organic Frameworks through a Bronsted Acid-Base Reaction for CO2 Capture
Li, Hao; Wang, Kecheng; Feng, Dawei; Chen, Ying-Pin; Verdegaal, Wolfgang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
ChemSusChem
(
2016

(

The escalating atm. CO2 concn. is one of the most urgent environmental concerns of our age. To effectively capture CO2, various materials have been studied. Among them, alkylamine-modified metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are considered to be promising candidates. In most cases, alkylamine mols. are integrated into MOFs through the coordination bonds formed between open metal sites (OMSs) and amine groups. Thus, the alkylamine d., as well as the corresponding CO2 uptake in MOFs, are severely restricted by the d. of OMSs. To overcome this limit, other approaches to incorporating alkylamine into MOFs are highly desired. We have developed a new method based on Bronsted acid-base reaction to tether alkylamines into Cr-MIL-101-SO3H for CO2 capture. A systematic optimization of the amine tethering process was also conducted to maximize the CO2 uptake of the modified MOF. Under the optimal amine tethering condition, the obtained tris(2-aminoethyl)amine-functionalized Cr-MIL-101-SO3H (Cr-MIL-101-SO3H-TAEA) has a cyclic CO2 uptake of 2.28 mmol g-1 at 150 mbar and 40 Â°C, and 1.12 mmol g-1 at 0.4 mbar and 20 Â°C. The low-cost starting materials and simple synthetic procedure for the prepn. of Cr-MIL-101-SO3H-TAEA suggest that it has the potential for large-scale prodn. and practical applications.

During the formation of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), metal centers can coordinate with the intended org. linkers, but also with solvent mols. In this case, subsequent activation by removal of the solvent mols. creates unsatd. open metal sites known to have a strong affinity to CO2 mols., but their interactions are still poorly understood. Common force fields typically underestimate by as much as 2 orders of magnitude the adsorption of CO2 in open-site Mg-MOF-74, which has emerged as a promising MOF for CO2 capture. We present a systematic procedure to generate force fields using high-level quantum chem. calcns. Monte Carlo simulations based on an ab initio force field generated for CO2 in Mg-MOF-74 shed some light on the interpretation of thermodn. data from flue gas in this material. The force field describes accurately the chem. of the open metal sites, and is transferable to other structures. This approach may serve in mol. simulations in general and in the study of fluid-solid interactions.

Selective capture of CO2, which is essential for natural gas purifn. and CO2 sequestration, has been reported in zeolites, porous membranes, and amine solns. However, all such systems require substantial energy input for release of captured CO2, leading to low energy efficiency and high cost. A new class of materials named metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has also been demonstrated to take up voluminous amts. of CO2. However, these studies have been largely limited to equil. uptake measurements, which are a poor predictor of sepn. ability, rather than the more industrially relevant kinetic (dynamic) capacity. Here, we report that a known MOF, Mg-MOF-74, with open magnesium sites, rivals competitive materials in CO2 capture, with 8.9 wt. % dynamic capacity, and undergoes facile CO2 release at significantly lower temp., 80 Â°C. Mg-MOF-74 offers an excellent balance between dynamic capacity and regeneration. These results demonstrate the potential of MOFs with open metal sites as efficient CO2 capture media.

Metal-org. framework (MOF) compds. M2(dhtp) (open metal M = Mg, Mn, Co, Ni, Zn; dhtp = 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalate) possess exceptionally large densities of open metal sites. By adsorbing one CH4 mol. per open metal, these sites alone can generate very large methane storage capacities, 160-174 cm3(STP)/cm3, approaching the DOE target of 180 cm3(STP)/cm3 for material-based methane storage at room temp. The adsorption isotherm measurements at 298 K and 35 bar for the five M2(dhtp) compds. yield excess methane adsorption capacities ranging from 149 to 190 cm3(STP)/cm3 (derived using their crystal densities), indeed roughly equal to the predicted, maximal adsorption capacities of the open metals (within Â±10%) in these MOFs. Among the five isostructural MOFs studied, Ni2(dhtp) exhibits the highest methane storage capacity, â¼200 cm3(STP)/cm3 in terms of abs. adsorption, potentially surpassing the DOE target by â¼10%. The neutron diffraction expts. clearly reveal that the primary CH4 adsorption occurs directly on the open metal sites. Initial 1st-principles calcns. show that the binding energies of CH4 on the open metal sites are significantly higher than those on typical adsorption sites in classical MOFs, consistent with the measured large heats of methane adsorption for these materials. The authors attribute the enhancement of the binding strength to the unscreened electrostatic interaction between CH4 and the coordinatively unsatd. metal ions.

Mg-MOF-74, one of the best metal-org. framework (MOF) materials for CO2 adsorption and sepn., was widely explored in CO2 capture. H2O effects on postcombustion CO2 capture in Mg-MOF-74 are evaluated by using a combination of Grand Canonical Monte Carlo and d. functional theory (DFT) simulations. Results show that in this MOF the CO2 adsorption capacity is decreased by the presence of H2O mols. linked to coordinatively unsatd. metal sites (CUMs). This effect is a consequence of the redn. of binding energy between CO2 and the H2O-coordinated Mg-MOF-74 framework. DFT calcns. indicate that such binding energy is much lower than that without coordinated H2O. More importantly, the difference of the binding energy between CO2 and CUM in a MOF and between CO2 and CUM-coordinated H2O are good descriptors to evaluate H2O effects on CO2 capture in MOFs with CUMs. At the same time, these studies further demonstrate that the CUMs in MOFs play an important role in their performance for CO2 capture from a practical stream contg. H2O and other impurities.

Understanding and controlling water stability of MOF-74

Metal org. framework (MOF) materials in general, and MOF-74 in particular, have promising properties for many technol. important processes. However, their instability under humid conditions severely restricts practical use. We show that this instability and the accompanying redn. of the CO2 uptake capacity of MOF-74 under humid conditions originate in the water dissocn. reaction H2O â OH + H at the metal centers. After this dissocn., the OH groups coordinate to the metal centers, explaining the redn. in the MOF's CO2 uptake capacity. This redn. thus strongly depends on the catalytic activity of MOF-74 towards the water dissocn. reaction. We further show that-while the water mols. themselves only have a negligible effect on the crystal structure of MOF-74-the OH and H products of the dissocn. reaction significantly weaken the MOF framework and lead to the obsd. crystal structure breakdown. With this knowledge, we propose a way to suppress this particular reaction by modifying the MOF-74 structure to increase the water dissocn. energy barrier and thus control the stability of the system under humid conditions.

Pore Space Partition in Metal-Organic Frameworks
Zhai, Quan-Guo; Bu, Xianhui; Zhao, Xiang; Li, Dong-Sheng; Feng, Pingyun

A review. The efforts to implement pore space partition (PSP) in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and impact of PSP on gas uptake performance are reviewed. In the synthetic design of PSP, it is helpful to distinguish between factors that contribute to the framework formation and factors that serve the purpose of PSP. Because of the need for complementary structural roles, the synthesis of MOFs with PSP often involves multicomponent systems including mixed ligands, mixed inorg. nodes, or both. It is possible to accomplish both framework formation and PSP with a single type of polyfunctional ligands that use some functional groups (called framework-forming group) for framework formation and the remaining functional groups (called pore-partition group) for PSP. Alternatively, framework formation and PSP can be shouldered by different chem. species. For example, in a mixed-ligand system, one ligand (called framework-forming agent) can play the role of the framework formation while the other type of ligand (called pore-partition agent) can assume the role of PSP. PSP is sensitive to the types of inorg. secondary building units (SBUs). The coexistence of SBUs complementary in charge, connectivity, and so on can promote PSP. The use of heterometallic systems can promote the diversity of SBUs coexistent under a given condition. Heterometallic system with metal ions of different oxidn. states also provides the charge tunability of SBUs and the overall framework, providing an addnl. level of control in self-assembly and ultimately in the materials' properties. Of particular interest is the PSP in MIL-88 type (acs-type topol.) structure, which has led to a huge family of CPMs (called pacs CPMs, pacs = partitioned acs) exhibiting low isosteric heat of adsorption and yet superior CO2 uptake capacity.

Using d. functional theory, the authors systematically computed and investigated the binding enthalpies of 14 different small mols. in a series of isostructural metal-org. frameworks, M-MOF-74, with M = Mg, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn. The small mols. considered include major flue-gas components, trace gases, and small hydrocarbons, i.e., H2, CO, CO2, H2O, H2S, N2, NH3, SO2, CH4, C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, and C3H8. In total, the adsorption energetics of 140 unique systems are presented and discussed. Dispersion interactions were included by employing a non-local van der Waals d. functional, vdW-DF2. Hubbard U corrections were applied to the localized d electrons of transition metal atoms, and the impact of such corrections was assessed quant. For systems for which measured binding enthalpies have been reported, these calcns. lead to excellent overall agreement with exptl. detd. structures and isosteric heats of adsorption. For systems that have yet to be realized or characterized, this study provides quant. predictions, establishes a better understanding of the role of different transition-metal cations in small-mol. binding at open-metal sites, and identifies routes for predicting potential candidates for energy-related gas-sepn. applications. For example, the authors predict that Cu-MOF-74 will exhibit selectivity of CO2 over H2O and that Mn-MOF-74 can be used to sep. trace flue-gas impurities and toxic gases from gas mixts.

A new mol. mechanics force field, the Universal force field (UFF), is described wherein the force field parameters are estd. using general rules based only on the element, its hybridization and its connectivity. The force field functional forms, parameters, and generating formulas for the full periodic table are presented.

Current gradient-cor. d.-functional approxns. for the exchange energies of at. and mol. systems fail to reproduce the correct 1/r asymptotic behavior of the exchange-energy d. A gradient-cor. exchange-energy functional is given with the proper asymptotic limit. This functional, contg. only one parameter, fits the exact Hartree-Fock exchange energies of a wide variety of at. systems with remarkable accuracy, surpassing the performance of previous functionals contg. two parameters or more.

Performance of B3LYP Density Functional Methods for a Large Set of Organic Molecules
Tirado-Rives, Julian; Jorgensen, William L.

(

.
(
American Chemical Society

Testing of the commonly used hybrid d. functional B3LYP with the 6-31G(d), 6-31G(d,p), and 6-31+G(d,p) basis sets has been carried out for 622 neutral, closed-shell org. compds. contg. the elements C, H, N, and O. The focus is comparison of computed and exptl. heats of formation and isomerization energies. In addn., the effect of an empirical dispersion correction term has been evaluated and found to improve agreement with the exptl. data. For the 622 compds., the mean abs. errors (MAE) in the heats of formation are 3.1, 2.6, 2.7, and 2.4 kcal/mol for B3LYP/6-31G(d), B3LYP/6-31G(d,p), B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p), and B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) with the dispersion correction. A diverse set of 34 isomerizations highlights specific issues of general interest, such as performance on differences in steric effects, conjugation, and bonding. The corresponding MAEs for the isomerizations are 2.7, 2.4, 2.2, and 1.9 kcal/mol. Improvement is obtained for isomerizations of amines and alcs. when both polarization and diffuse functions are used, but the overstabilization of linear alkanes compared to branched isomers can be relieved only with the dispersion correction. Besides the insights on DFT methods, the study also aimed to quantify the gains in accuracy that can be achieved by replacing energetics from NDO-based semiempirical methods with DFT results. Since the MAEs obtained with the PDDG/PM3 method for the 622 heats of formation and 34 isomerizations are 2.8 and 2.3 kcal/mol, negligible advantage in accuracy for the B3LYP-based methods emerged in the absence of the dispersion corrections.

A combined experimental and quantum chemical study of CO2 adsorption in the metal-organic framework CPO-27 with different metals
Yu, Decai; Yazaydin, A. Ozgur; Lane, Joseph R.; Dietzel, Pascal D. C.; Snurr, Randall Q.
Chemical Science
(

CODEN:
CSHCCN
; ISSN:
2041-6520
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A first principles study of CO2 adsorption is presented for a group of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) known as CPO-27-M, where M = Mg, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn. These materials consist of one-dimensional channels with a high concn. of open metal sites and have been identified as among the most promising MOFs for CO2 capture. In addn., extensive, high-pressure, exptl. adsorption results are reported for CO2, CH4, and N2 at temps. ranging from 278 K to 473 K. Isosteric heats of adsorption were calcd. from the variable-temp. isotherms. The binding energies of CO2 calcd. using an MP2-based QM/MM method are in good agreement with those obtained from expts. The relative CO2 binding strengths for the different transition metals can be explained by the relative strength of electrostatic interactions caused by the effective charge of the metal atom in the direction of the open metal site induced by incomplete screening of 3d electrons. The Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu versions of CPO-27 are predicted to be anti-ferromagnetic in their ground states. Selectivities for CO2 over CH4 or N2 were calcd. from the exptl. isotherms using ideal adsorbed soln. theory.
